Name: Svenja Frey
Background: I am working in climate science, specifically with climate models, so the data that we are usually working with is unbelievably large and has multiple 4D variables (time, latitude, longitude, depth). Therefore, I am interested in applying ML to reduce those data sizes to more "manageable" timeseries or fields. However, there are also commonly used 1D climate indexes (e.g. AMOC), where we are interested in their interaction with each other and if ML can be leveraged to analyze very long timeseries efficiently. More precisely, we have about 15000 years of monthly data with circa 100x100x30 latxlonxdepth resultion from the last glacial period from an earth system model.
ML_Experience: I have taken multiple university courses on ML during my Master and am currently working on my thesis topic that involves using ML in climate science. However, it feels like I have just "scratched the surface" of the possibilities of ML in physics / climate science, and I am very excited to learn and explore more.
Motivation: I am specifically interested in ML methods that bridge the gap between machine learning (an inherently statistical tool) and the causal structures that we are interested in studying in climate science. We don't necessarily care if things are correlated, but whether they are causally connected. This is a very difficult task, so I hope to expand on this during the summer school and see how this problem can be dealt with in new ML applications (e.g. Physics informed ML).

By integrating machine learning into his research, Luca is pioneering new methodologies to analyze complex datasets from various colliders, ultimately aiming to deepen the understanding of particle interactions at the fundamental level.

As an emerging researcher in the application of machine learning to particle physics, Luca aims to explore innovative techniques for analyzing collider data. His current focus on deploying neural networks, particularly Bayesian Neural Networks, is an exciting experimental endeavor within the AIPHY project. Luca's interest lies not only in implementing machine learning models but also in enhancing their explainability and optimizing fitting pipelines. His proactive engagement in learning Keras, Tensorflow, and Pytorch underpins his commitment to mastering these tools for research progression.

Luca is dedicated to optimizing fitting algorithms used in the NNPDF framework to improve the extraction of Parton Distribution Functions from experimental data. This involves experimenting with various computational methods and leveraging machine learning techniques to streamline the fitting process. His aim is to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of obtaining PDFs, allowing for more precise predictions in high-energy physics experiments. Through his collaboration with experienced researchers, Luca is eager to learn and incorporate advanced optimization strategies into his methodologies.

Name: Archi Gupta
Background: Hii, I am a PhD student in the University of Geneva. The goal of my PhD project is to build single photon sources using the platform of rare earth ions. In this project, I am doing simulations based on Tidy3D and using optimisation algorithm like BFGS to determine the optimal parameters for the nano cavity which I want to fabricate to achieve high Purcell enhancement.    Before my PhD, I have also worked with quantum algorithms (BV algorithm) to determine its efficiency over classical algorithm.    I am quite motivated to learn machine learning as it will be really useful in many tasks related to quantum information.
ML_Experience: I don't have any machine learning experience but I am excited to learn about it.
Motivation: I hope to learn more about improving algorithms and machine learning in order to be able to do tasks like error correction and data analysis.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Hii is focusing on developing single photon sources using rare earth ions during her PhD at the University of Geneva. This involves complex simulations with Tidy3D and implementing optimization algorithms like BFGS to fine-tune the parameters for a nano cavity. Her ultimate goal is to achieve a high Purcell enhancement, which is critical for advancements in quantum technologies and applications.

Prior to her PhD, Hii worked on quantum algorithms, specifically examining the efficiency of the Bernstein-Vazirani (BV) algorithm compared to classical counterparts. Her experiences in this area have provided her with a strong foundation in quantum computational theory and algorithms, which she leverages to enhance her current research into photonic sources. She is eager to further explore how quantum algorithms can influence the development of quantum technologies.

Although Hii currently has no experience in machine learning, she is highly motivated to learn how it can be applied within quantum information tasks. Her interests lie in employing machine learning techniques for enhancing algorithmic efficiency, particularly in error correction and data analysis. Hii believes that integrating machine learning with her background in quantum mechanics will be pivotal for her growth as a researcher.

Name: ALEXANDRA HASLUNDGOURLEY
Background: I'm a Computational Physics Master's student at KU, passionate about the intersection of machine learning and physics. My research interests flow in both directions: I currently work with KU's Dr. Inar Timiryasov and Dr. Jean-Loup Tastet, applying physics-inspired analysis to understand the computational mechanisms of large language models. We focus on analyzing activation matrices produced by these models, employing statistical methods to characterize their behavior as complex dynamical systems.    This summer, and for my thesis work, I plan to explore how diffusion models can predict stable atomic configurations. I'll ground this research using DTU's Computational 2D Materials Database (C2DB), which contains structural, thermodynamic, elastic, electronic, magnetic, and optical properties of approximately 4,000 two-dimensional materials across over 40 different crystal structures. My goal is to incorporate physics priors into these models to produce more reliable and interpretable predictions, following the approach outlined in “A generative artificial intelligence framework based on a molecular diffusion model for the design of metal-organic frameworks for carbon capture”.
ML_Experience: My formal ML education includes courses in unsupervised learning, computer vision, and deep learning. I spent a year as a research fellow at Stanford applying computer vision for environmental monitoring. In my current LLM mechanistic interpretability research, I run inference with and fine-tune open-source models while extracting mid-computation activation matrices for analysis. Additionally, I've used graph neural networks to predict band gap energies of molecules as part of an advanced statistics course.
Motivation: I aim to strengthen my skills in physics-informed machine learning and gain deeper insights into how ML can enhance our modeling and understanding of physical systems. I'm excited to learn from both the distinguished speakers and fellow participants, and to engage in hands-on exercises. I'm particularly interested in methods that integrate physics priors into models, as well as approaches that use physics to interpret and demystify model behavior—an area I consider crucial for making ML more transparent and trustworthy in scientific applications.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: As a Master's student at the University of Copenhagen, [Name] is exploring the intersection of machine learning and physics, specifically focusing on physics-inspired models that enhance the interpretability of machine learning predictions. This research includes analyzing activation matrices of large language models to understand their behavior as complex dynamical systems. By integrating physics principles into machine learning frameworks, [Name] aims to develop models that are not only predictive but also reliable and interpretable, making significant contributions to the field of computational physics.

[Name] is leveraging diffusion models to predict stable atomic configurations, applying these techniques to explore two-dimensional materials utilizing DTU's Computational 2D Materials Database. This research involves analyzing a diverse array of properties across thousands of materials, with the goal of generating robust predictions informed by physical insights. [Name]'s evolving expertise in computational materials science underlines an ambition to bridge machine learning with material discovery, ultimately advancing the understanding of material behavior and characteristics.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Mechanistic Interpretability in Large Language Models
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: [Name] actively investigates the mechanistic interpretability of large language models through the extraction and analysis of mid-computation activation matrices. This research involves fine-tuning open-source models while employing advanced statistical methods. By incorporating graph neural networks to predict molecular properties, [Name] seeks to elucidate the functioning of these complex models, enhancing transparency and trustworthiness in their application within scientific research. This focus on deciphering the underlying mechanisms of machine learning models is essential for the responsible adoption of AI technologies.

Name: Zineb Hayar
Affiliation: University Mohamed V - Faculty of Sciences Rabat
Background: I am a PhD student in Mathematical Physics working on the application of AI to study neutrino signals from astronomical objects in the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. My research involves analyzing large-scale datasets containing neutrino event features such as energy, time, and spatial distributions. These datasets may be structured and either labeled or unlabeled. Additionally, I focus on the design and development of deployment systems for AI-based data analysis. My goal is to leverage machine learning for event classification, anomaly detection, and enhanced signal extraction.
ML_Experience: I am in the early stages of integrating Machine Learning into my PhD research. I have a strong background in Mathematical Physics and have learned Python through CS50’s Introduction to Programming with Python. I am currently studying AI applications in neutrino physics and learning relevant ML techniques for event classification and signal extraction. While I do not yet have extensive hands-on experience, I am actively developing my skills to apply ML effectively in my research, including data analysis and model deployment.
Motivation: At the school, I hope to deepen my understanding of Machine Learning techniques relevant to physics, particularly for analyzing complex datasets and optimizing AI models. I aim to learn best practices for data preprocessing, feature extraction, and model deployment in a scientific context. With my data, I seek to improve neutrino event classification, enhance signal extraction, and develop a robust deployment system for AI-driven analysis in the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. Ultimately, I want to bridge the gap between theoretical physics and AI, making meaningful contributions to data-driven discoveries in neutrino astrophysics.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Mohammed is focused on the integration of Artificial Intelligence techniques in the study of neutrino signals from astronomical objects in the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. His research navigates through vast datasets containing various neutrino event features, including energy levels and spatial distributions. By deploying machine learning methodologies, he aspires to classify events and detect anomalies, thereby enhancing the extraction of significant signals from data that is either structured or unstructured. Mohammed aims to contribute to a better understanding of neutrino behaviors while pushing the boundaries of AI applications in astrophysics.

As a PhD researcher, Mohammed is actively exploring various machine learning techniques that are essential for event classification and signal detection within his research. He is currently equipping himself with knowledge about data preprocessing, feature extraction, and model deployment tailored to scientific contexts. Mohammed is keen on refining these techniques to address the complexities of the large-scale neutrino datasets, ultimately aiming to achieve optimal performance in AI-driven analyses. His motivation stems from a desire to master these ML methodologies to facilitate significant contributions in the intersection of machine learning and physics.

Mohammed is dedicated to the design and development of robust deployment systems for AI-based data analysis specifically within the framework of his mathematical physics research. He understands that successful deployment of machine learning models is crucial for translating theoretical insights into practical applications. By developing precise strategies for analyzing large-scale datasets and ensuring seamless deployment of AI models, he aims to create a systematic approach that can be utilized in the Hyper-Kamiokande experiment. Mohammed’s goal is to culminate his knowledge in mathematical physics and AI into pragmatic solutions that enhance scientific inquiry in neutrino astrophysics.

Name: Andreas M. Hermansen
Background: I did my MSc improving the Neutrino reconstruction in IceCube using Machine Learning, and am currently doing an interdisciplinary PhD between Physics and Computer Science working on Machine Learning applied to High Energy Physics. In particular I am currently working on how to transfer the success of modern foundation models to the physical sciences. In particular the ATLAS experiment.
ML_Experience: I have was experience working with machine learning models. Both implementing them and using them to properly analyse data. The majority of my MSc degree was spent working on various aspects of data analysis (statistics and ML), which culminated in my Master's thesis which centered around improving the current ML tools used in the IceCube experiment.
Motivation: I hope to meet other early career scientists who have experience with ML, with whom I can share ideas and broaden my view of ML applications in science.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Machine Learning in High Energy Physics
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Luca is exploring the intersection of physics and computing, focusing on harnessing the power of machine learning to enhance the analysis of high energy physics data. His interdisciplinary PhD work emphasizes transferring the efficacy of modern foundation models into practical applications within the ATLAS experiment at CERN. His goal is to develop innovative methodologies that incorporate advanced machine learning techniques to improve data reconstruction and event classification, which can lead to significant breakthroughs in the understanding of fundamental particles and forces.

Having a solid foundation from his Master's thesis, where he worked on improving neutrino reconstruction in the IceCube experiment, Luca is dedicated to refining current methodologies in particle detection. He aims to implement cutting-edge machine learning algorithms that could drastically enhance the accuracy of neutrino detection and characterization, facilitating new discoveries in astrophysics and particle physics. His previous experience enables him to bridge theoretical frameworks with practical implementations that contribute to ongoing research efforts.

Luca is keen on fostering collaborative efforts among early career scientists, particularly those engaged in machine learning applications across various scientific domains. He believes that cross-disciplinary engagement can lead to innovative solutions and the propagation of ideas that benefit the wider scientific community. His motivation to connect with others in the field reflects his desire to share knowledge, exchange insights on machine learning, and collectively advance the frontiers of physical science.

Name: Rabia Husain
Background: I am a fourth year PhD student studying particle phenomenology. Specifically I work on problems in collider physics, with a focus on the LHC. I am currently working on a project which aims to improve tagging u vs d jets at the LHC with the inclusion of pT weighted jet charge information. To do so, I am looking at large sets of data generated by Pythia and Delphes. These datasets are around 2M events, formatted as text files which I preprocess into the h5 format before feeding into the networks. We include labels such as momentum, charge, and PID.
ML_Experience: My project on tagging u vs d jets is my first experience using ML. While I have studied the topic previously, I do not have much hands on experience yet, but I hope to incorporate ML into other projects that I am working on. Right now, I am working on another project which aims to reconstruct the rational coefficients of a function given its basis functions by sampling the function and its basis functions at particular points with a given precision. We hope to use ML to help us pick these points, though we have yet to implement this.
Motivation: I hope to learn about more advanced topics in ML at this school, such as representation learning and generative machine learning. Since I am a beginner in the ML field, gaining more knowledge about these topics will help me open up the type of research I am able to do. In addition I would like to learn more about the challenges of ML, including uncertainty quantification. With with this knowledge, I want to improve the techniques I am using to do my current research, as well as expand upon my work into future research directions.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: As a fourth year PhD student at Harvard University, I am deeply engaged in the study of collider physics, with a particular emphasis on the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). My current research explores innovative methods of tagging u versus d jets by incorporating pT weighted jet charge information. This project entails analyzing extensive datasets generated by simulation tools like Pythia and Delphes, consisting of around 2 million events. I preprocess these datasets into h5 format and integrate crucial labels, such as momentum, charge, and PID, to enhance our ability to classify jets accurately. Through this work, I aim to contribute to the field of particle phenomenology and improve jet identification techniques in high-energy physics experiments.

My journey into machine learning (ML) began with my project on tagging jets in collider physics. This is my first foray into the practical applications of ML, though I have previously studied the theories behind it. I am currently involved in developing a method to reconstruct the rational coefficients of a function using its basis functions, where we sample both the function and its basis at specific points. I aim to leverage ML techniques to optimize these sampling points to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of our reconstruction process. By integrating ML into my research, I hope to not only improve current methodologies but also explore new avenues in computational physics.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Exploration of Advanced Machine Learning Techniques
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: At this stage in my PhD journey, I am highly motivated to expand my knowledge in advanced machine learning topics, particularly in representation learning and generative machine learning. As I am at the beginning of my ML endeavors, gaining insights into these advanced concepts will empower me to tackle more complex problems in my research. Furthermore, I am keen on understanding the intricacies of uncertainty quantification within ML, as it is vital for any physicist applying these methods to real-world data. My goal is to assimilate this knowledge to refine my current research techniques and pave the way for innovative future projects in the realms of particle physics and beyond.

Name: Nico Härringer
Background: I work in high-energy physics, focusing on detector development and data analysis within the CMS experiment at CERN. My research includes studying radiation effects on electronics and performing data analysis using the Higgs boson. Primarily, I study the decay of a Higgs into two photons.
ML_Experience: Currently, I don’t have much hands-on ML experience yet, but I’m eager to change that. One of my current research projects already includes ML techniques, and I want to understand them properly rather than just using them as a black box. By the end of summer, I expect to work more on Physics Object reconstruction (especially electrons and photons), where ML is becoming increasingly important. This school would be a perfect opportunity to get up to speed and apply ML methods effectively in my work.
Motivation: I want to build a solid foundation in Machine Learning and understand how to apply it to HEP problems in a meaningful way. My goal is to gain the confidence to implement ML methods in my own research rather than relying solely on predefined tools. By applying what I learn here, I hope to contribute more effectively to my group and the collaboration.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Currently, as a PhD student at ETH Zürich, I am deeply engaged in high-energy physics with a specific focus on detector development and data analysis within the CMS experiment at CERN. My primary research revolves around studying the radiation effects on electronics in high-energy environments. A significant aspect of my work includes analyzing the behavior and decay processes of the Higgs boson, particularly the decay of the Higgs into two photons. This area is not only crucial for understanding fundamental particle physics but also contributes to advancing detector technology that can handle upcoming experimental challenges.

Although I currently have limited hands-on experience in machine learning, I am eager to immerse myself in this transformative field. One of my ongoing projects has already integrated ML techniques, and I'm keen to deepen my understanding beyond treating these methods as a black box. By the end of the summer, I aim to focus on Physics Object reconstruction, specifically targeting electrons and photons, where ML is becoming increasingly indispensable. I believe that mastering these techniques will be pivotal for my research on high-energy physics experiments, enhancing both precision and efficiency.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Application of ML to Physics Research
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: My overarching motivation is to build a robust foundation in machine learning to effectively apply these methods to high-energy physics problems. I am determined to gain the expertise and confidence needed to implement ML strategies in my research work, thereby moving from reliance on predefined tools to creating tailor-made solutions. By leveraging the knowledge and skills acquired from this school, I aspire to contribute meaningfully to my research group and the broader collaboration within the field, ensuring that my work pushes the boundaries of current understanding in high-energy physics.

Name: Johann Ioannou-Nikolaides
Affiliation: Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen
Background: I am working on neutrino physics. I am interested both in particle physics (neutrino oscillations) and astrophysics (discovering sources in the Universe that emit neutrinos)
ML_Experience: On a scale from Novice to Specialist, Researcher, I would call myself an engineer. I have had some experience with various Machine Learning algorithms on a limited number of datasets O(10) and a similar number of tasks. I would say that I have had the joy to work on various problems, but I am not yet at the level where I am following and implementing the latest developments in Machine Learning and AI.
Motivation: I want to learn more about AI and become eventually an AI researcher.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Niels is deeply engaged in the study of neutrino physics, focusing on the fascinating phenomena of neutrino oscillations. His work centers on understanding how neutrinos, elusive particles that are produced in nuclear reactions, can change from one type to another as they travel through the universe. This aspect of particle physics is crucial for understanding the fundamental forces of nature and the composition of the universe. Niels aims to contribute significantly to experimental and theoretical approaches in this field, thereby enhancing our knowledge of neutrinos and their implications for physics.

In addition to his work in particle physics, Niels has a keen interest in astrophysics, particularly in the quest to identify cosmic sources that emit neutrinos. He explores questions such as where these high-energy particles come from and what astrophysical processes lead to their production. By investigating supernovae, black holes, and other extreme cosmic events, Niels hopes to uncover the mysteries of the universe and understand how such astronomical phenomena contribute to the overall picture of particle physics and cosmic evolution.

Niels is eager to bridge the gap between physics and artificial intelligence by applying machine learning techniques to his research in neutrino physics and astrophysics. Although he self-identifies as an engineer with novice-level experience in machine learning, he is enthusiastic about enhancing his skills in this area. Niels understands the transformative power of AI in analyzing complex datasets and modeling physical phenomena and aims to develop a solid understanding of machine learning algorithms and their applications in modern physics research.

Name: Joaquín Iturriza Ramírez
Background: I'm working on phenomenology in particle physics. At the moment I'm studying the scaling behaviour of different network architectures in the prediction of scattering amplitudes from the momentum of the initial and final particles, varying the number of training data points, loop order, number of particles in the process, etc. Before my current project, as part of my PhD under Anja Butter I worked on the prediction of likelihoods with ML for BSM processes. Specifically focusing on uncertainties using a heteroscedastic loss function.
ML_Experience: Due to my current PhD, I’m working with state of the art architectures for particle physics and methods for uncertainty estimation in ML. So, I have knowledge from the theoretical point of view and in concrete implementations for particle physics.
Motivation: I’m particularly interested in uncertainty estimation and Bayesian NNs, but in general I hope to keep up with the newest advancements and learn new concepts to apply in my PhD research.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: In his current research, the PhD student is delving into the phenomenology of particle physics, focusing on understanding the scaling behavior of various network architectures. He is investigating how these architectures predict scattering amplitudes based on the momenta of both initial and final particles. By manipulating factors such as the number of training data points, loop order, and the number of particles involved, he aims to refine the precision of particle interactions. This work is foundational for improving predictive models in high-energy physics.

He possesses a solid foundation in machine learning applications for particle physics, particularly in estimating uncertainties concerning Beyond Standard Model (BSM) processes. His previous work involved the utilization of a heteroscedastic loss function to better predict likelihoods in uncertain environments. This approach enhances the reliability of ML models and provides crucial insights into BSM scenarios, which are vital for advancing theoretical predictions in physics.

The student's motivation includes a keen interest in Bayesian Neural Networks (NNs), exploring their potential in providing effective uncertainty estimation in predictions related to particle physics. He aims to stay abreast of the latest advancements in this field, aspiring to implement innovative concepts into his PhD research. By harnessing the power of Bayesian methods, he hopes to enhance the robustness and credibility of his findings in particle interaction predictions.

Name: Marc Jacquart
Affiliation: Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen
Background: I am currently working on inelasticity reconstruction of simulated data (~3 millions neutrino events) using the GraphNeT library to get sensitivity of the IceCube Upgrade detector.
ML_Experience: Multiple academic project in high energy physics (LHCb, CMS & IceCube experiments) for classification and regression of relevant quantities in particle interactions.
Motivation: Discover new methods to apply machine learning to problems in physics. I am working on uncertainty quantification from my model as inelasticity is a hard quantity to reconstruct. So I am particularly interested by this part and the "Bayesian neural networks" topics.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Machine Learning in High Energy Physics
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Being part of multiple academic projects in high energy physics, including contributions to LHCb, CMS, and IceCube experiments, the researcher, currently a Ph.D. student, is excited about the application of machine learning techniques to particle physics. They focus on classification and regression tasks pertinent to particle interactions, aiming to enhance data analysis efficiency and accuracy. Their work is pivotal in transforming complex data sets into understandable insights, especially when dealing with vast neutrino event data.

This project entails handling around 3 million neutrino events while aiming to determine the sensitivity of the IceCube Upgrade detector. By developing innovative algorithms and methodologies in this domain, the researcher seeks to improve the accuracy of inelasticity reconstructions, which is critical for understanding fundamental physics processes.

research_interests.research_interest_title: Uncertainty Quantification and Bayesian Neural Networks
research_interests.research_interest_long_description: With a keen interest in uncertainty quantification, the researcher focuses on Bayesian neural networks as a formidable approach to tackling the challenges associated with reconstructing inelasticity. This area of study is vital in providing a quantified measure of uncertainty in their models, offering deeper insights into the reliability of the predictions made. The researcher aims to develop methods that will allow for robust uncertainty assessments associated with machine learning models in high-energy physics.

Name: Pablo Jimenez
Affiliation: University of Heidelberg, German Cancer Research Center (DKFZ)
Background: My PhD research focuses on Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) in medicine, specifically designing MRI protocols for a newly developed local gradient breast coil aimed at early breast cancer detection. The project addresses challenges posed by high gradient inhomogeneities in the coil. One of the possibilities is to apply Machine Learning and Bayesian neural networks to optimize MRI parameters (gradient intensity, diffusion time, b-value) for enhanced diffusion information and better detection of abnormalities, considering the particular gradient inhomogeneities. The dataset consists of 30+ samples, each containing 5 MRI images (128x256 pixels, ~26MB in “twix” format), acquired with varying parameters.
ML_Experience: I have completed a 128-hour postgraduate course on Neural Networks and another 128-hour course on Deep Learning applied to image processing. Additionally, I have worked for 2 years applying Deep Learning techniques for segmentation in medical images. While I am familiar with the core concepts and techniques, I do not have extensive knowledge in Bayesian models or Physics-Informed Neural Networks, which are central to my project.
Motivation: Given that the problem I aim to address with Machine Learning techniques is specific, and my research expertise does not focus on this area, this school could provide me with valuable insights into various projects where groups from unrelated fields are applying these techniques, allowing me to connect them to my own work. I also aim to deepen my understanding of Bayesian and Physics-Informed Neural Networks, learning about their advantages and limitations, which I believe are crucial for the success of this part of my project.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: Max's PhD research is centered around the development of advanced Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) protocols using a newly designed local gradient breast coil. This innovative approach aims to improve early breast cancer detection by addressing the challenges posed by high gradient inhomogeneities within the coil. By optimizing various MRI parameters such as gradient intensity, diffusion time, and b-value, Max is dedicated to enhancing the quality of diffusion information and increasing the accuracy of abnormality detection in breast imaging.

Max is exploring the application of Machine Learning techniques, particularly Bayesian neural networks, to optimize MRI parameters for breast cancer detection. With a robust background in Neural Networks and Deep Learning, he seeks to integrate these advanced methodologies into his MRI protocols to improve diagnostic effectiveness. His research involves analyzing a dataset of over 30 samples with multiple MRI images to leverage machine learning for enhanced medical imaging and analysis, focusing on tackling gradient inhomogeneities critical to his project.

To further his understanding of Bayesian modeling, Max is keenly interested in learning and applying Bayesian neural networks within his research. He recognizes the significance of these models in providing a probabilistic approach to inference, which could enhance his capabilities in optimizing MRI protocols. Max is motivated to explore the advantages and limitations of Bayesian neural networks, aiming to incorporate this knowledge into his work, thereby enabling more informed decision-making in medical imaging processes related to breast cancer detection.

Name: Julie Kiel Holm
Background: I work with stellar streams and we are considering the possibility of using ML to find streams in images from the Euclid telescope (which we don't have yet).
ML_Experience: Very basic knowledge.
Motivation: To expand my toolbox and gain sufficient insight into the strengths and weaknesses of different ML methods to give qualified estimates of their usability in stream finding algorithms.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: The researcher, currently a PhD student, is focused on understanding stellar streams and their significance in the study of galaxy formation and evolution. Their research aims to deepen our understanding of these cosmic phenomena and how they can be leveraged to advance our knowledge of the universe.

While they possess basic knowledge of machine learning, they are motivated to expand their skills to effectively implement various algorithms. Their goal is to evaluate the strengths and limitations of different ML methods in identifying and classifying stellar features, which could revolutionize data analysis in astronomy.

As part of their doctoral research, the student is preparing for the future influx of data from the Euclid telescope. They are dedicated to devising innovative strategies for utilizing this data, particularly in the context of detecting and analyzing stellar streams. They recognize the importance of developing robust algorithms that not only identify stellar features in the images but also effectively categorize them, setting a foundational understanding for further astronomical exploration.

Name: Filip Klimovič
Background: My thesis topic lies within the field of condensed matter theory, focusing on terahertz spectroscopy of semiconductor nanostructures, the research of which can possibly lead to miniaturization and energy efficiency enhancement of opto-electronic devices. We develop models to properly describe light-matter interactions on quantum-mechanical level, finding solutions through relatively costly (computational power-wise) finite element method (FEM) electromagnetic calculations. My aim is to optimize the identification of regions of interest in the input parameter space (including all possible geometries of the nanostructured material) for analysis of e.g. plasmonic resonances.
ML_Experience: As a part of my PhD course, I am enrolled in a programme called ‘prg.ai minor’. I have passed subjects on the rigorous foundations of Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence, as well as more applied ones focused on Natural Language Processing. I am still looking for a way to apply ML on my research project.
Motivation: Foremost, I would like to broaden my overview of the new possibilities of ML applications in physics. I understand it is a big thing in experimental data-heavy fields like particle physics and I am interested to see, how condensed matter theory can benefit from the rapid ML development. Concerning my own data, I want to find a smart way of choosing of input parameter set where to look next, based on already calculated results. Finally, I want to start looking into the question, whether some nanostructured metamaterials could be designed to mimic the function of neural networks, such as temporal memory and nonlinear activation.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: My research focuses on condensed matter theory with a particular emphasis on terahertz spectroscopy of semiconductor nanostructures. These studies aim to advance the miniaturization and energy efficiency of opto-electronic devices. By developing models to accurately describe light-matter interactions at the quantum mechanical level, I apply finite element method (FEM) electromagnetic calculations to find effective solutions. My goal is to optimize the identification of areas within the input parameter space in order to enhance the analysis of phenomena such as plasmonic resonances.

As part of my PhD program, I am exploring the integration of machine learning with condensed matter physics. Having completed rigorous coursework in both fundamental and applied machine learning, specifically in Natural Language Processing, I aim to identify innovative applications of ML in my research. I am particularly interested in leveraging ML techniques to optimize the selection of input parameters based on previously computed results, thereby enhancing the efficiency of my studies in condensed matter theory.

I am intrigued by the potential of designing nanostructured metamaterials that could mimic neural network functions, such as temporal memory and nonlinear activation. This interest stems from my goal to explore new frontiers at the intersection of physics and artificial intelligence. I believe that understanding how these metamaterials can replicate neural functionalities could open up new avenues in both condensed matter theory and machine learning applications. My research endeavors will include investigating how such designs can contribute to the evolution of intelligent systems.

Name: Júlia Križanová
Background: I am a master's computer science specializing in optimization which I feel like is particularly useful when it comes to understanding the ML in the practical applications. My undergraduate studies focused solely on AI and machine learning, so I feel like this is a valuable combination of knowledge.    During my studies I also had part-time job at pharmaceutical company as a data scientist with focus on computer vision, where I was working with complex medical datasets.    Before starting my master I spent summer at Rutgers University as research intern under Professor Jie Gao, studying behavior of large crowds correctly learning some ground truth information in social/adversarial setting. The work was rather theoretical, but has practical implications in the learning of LLMS.

In the final year I successfully completed the student grant under the physics department focusing on detecting kaons and pions on RICH detector in the AMBER experiment at CERN with the help of neural network.    My master is oriented more in mathematical aspect of ML, specifically optimization. I focus on (non)linear programming, optimization and game theoretical aspects.     Moreover, I am enrolled in AI minor programme, which is a joint degree with Czech technical university, enabling students to broaden the knowledge in machine learning, have better knowledge of the current trends in the area etc.

This interest stems from my previous stay at CERN where I had shifts at AMBER control room for 2 weeks, controlling the correctness of data taking during the run of the experiment last spring.

research_interests.research_interest_long_description: In his master's program, he focuses on the mathematical aspects of machine learning, particularly optimization. He explores both linear and nonlinear programming, delving into game theory to understand competitive and cooperative environments within machine learning frameworks. This unique angle allows him to create more efficient algorithms and contribute to the development of robust AI systems. He firmly believes that optimization is key to maximizing the performance of machine learning models in real-world applications, and his background in computer science positions him to bridge theory with practical implementation effectively.

He has practical experience as a data scientist in the pharmaceutical industry, where he worked specifically on computer vision. This role involved processing and analyzing complex medical datasets, aiming to extract meaningful insights that could improve patient outcomes.
